title: Can Trump convince voters on the US economy?
summary:
The timing of the president’s speech comes after polling suggests the Republican Party is losing support over the direction of the economy.
Will Republicans be able to convince voters that they should still be trusted on the economy ahead of next year’s midterms?

title: There's One Thing Trump Could Do To Turbocharge The Global Economy And Crush Inflation
summary:
There's no indication that tariffs will suddenly be removed, but the paper highlighted the extreme impact they've had on the global economy.
President Donald Trump could invigorate the global economy and stamp out inflation quickly.
That's a boost of 0.5 percentage points per year, all while reducing inflation for U.S. consumers.
"One year after "liberation day," the U.S. administration starts lowering U.S. tariffs back to the levels at end-2024."
Liberation from "Liberation Day" would not only reinvigorate global trade, but would help household budgets for U.S. consumers.

title: Inflation drops to lowest level in months, defying expectations of uptick
summary:
People shop at a grocery store in Brooklyn on December 12, 2025 in New York City.
Inflation dropped in November, ending a monthslong acceleration of price increases and offering relief for households strained by cost hikes, government data on Thursday showed.
The report offered the first look at price increases in nearly two months, after the 43-day government shutdown impaired data collection.
The White House touted the inflation report as a sign of progress in in its effort to slow price increases.
"There's no risk-free path for policy as we navigate this tension between our employment and inflation goals," Powell added.

title: Calculated Risk: Ten Economic Questions for 2026
summary:
1) Economic growth: Economic growth was probably close to 2% Q4-over-Q4 in 2025.
3) Unemployment Rate: The unemployment rate was at 4.6% in November, up from 4.2% in November 2024.
Will the core inflation rate decrease further in 2026, and what will the YoY core inflation rate be in December 2026?
Currently the FOMC is projecting the unemployment rate will decrease to the 4.3% to 4.4% range in Q4 2026.
Long term, the BLS is projecting the overall participation rate will decline to 61.1% by 2034 due to demographics.

title: Trump announces 'warrior dividend' for troops as he defends economic record
summary:
Trump announces 'warrior dividend' for troops as he defends economic record4 days ago Share Save Bernd Debusmann Jr , Washington and Anthony Zurcher , North America correspondent Share SaveWatch: Trump says service members will receive $1,776 "warrior dividend"US President Donald Trump has announced a "warrior dividend" payment to US service members, in a speech in which he also defended his track record on the economy after 11 months back in office.
In a televised address to the nation on Wednesday, Trump said cheques for $1,776 (£1,329) for 1.45 million US service members were already on the way" and should arrive before Christmas.
In the combative address, Trump also touted his achievements on immigration while railing against opposition Democrats.
Schumer added: "People are feeling squeezed harder and harder every day and tonight Donald Trump took a victory lap."
In the brief, 18-minute address, Trump said the "warrior dividend", which totals $2.57bn (£1.9bn), would be distributed "in honour of our nation's founding in 1776".

title: Average US long-term mortgage rate edges lower, remaining near its low for the year
summary:
The average rate on a 30-year U.S. mortgage edged lower this week, staying relatively close to its low for the year.
The decline brings the average long-term mortgage rate to 6.21% from 6.22% last week, mortgage buyer Freddie Mac said Thursday.
Mortgage rates began easing in July in anticipation of a series of Fed rate cuts, which began in September and continued this month.
That can help lower yields on long-term U.S. Treasurys, which can result in lower mortgage rates.
Even so, Fed rate cuts don’t always translate into lower mortgage rates.

title: Long lines at the food pantry: Inflation tests Trump’s base in Michigan
summary:
CAPAC, Michigan, Dec 21 (Reuters) - On a recent snowy morning in a Trump-loving part of rural Michigan, three dozen cars idled outside a firehouse-turned-food pantry.
Ludwig said she had expected Trump to have made greater ​progress on inflation nearly a year into his presidency.
But now, persistent inflation is testing that pledge — and the patience of voters who helped put him in office.
A dozen said they would still vote Republican, and three said they were unsure or did not share their voting plans.

title: ‘This is a wacky number’: economists cry foul as new government data assumes zero housing inflation in surprising November drop
summary:
But for many economists, the numbers immediately raised red flags, especially on housing, the single largest component of inflation.
When housing is that large a component, that really matters.”The culprit, several economists say, is the extended government shutdown, which disrupted the Bureau of Labor Statistics’ ability to collect price data throughout October and into November.
Instead, it relied on statistical assumptions—often “carrying forward” previous prices—that effectively treated some categories as if inflation had stopped altogether.
“This was one flawed CPI report,” he wrote.
Normally, market watchers would expect a meaningful drop in inflation would spark a sharp rally in stocks—or, in these days of bad data being good and good data being bad—a selloff as markets reprice interest-rate expectations.

title: New government research exposes the culprits behind massive energy cost increases: 'Prices are expected to continue rising'
summary:
U.S. energy prices are expected to continue to go up next year, according to new data from the Energy Information Administration.
Why are rising energy costs concerning?
For Americans already dealing with higher prices for things like groceries and rent, higher energy costs are a punch in the gut.
One way to help protect yourself from rising energy prices is to invest in solar.

title: Young people to be hit hardest by UK's ageing society, report suggests
summary:
Young people will feel burden of UK's ageing society, report suggestsCommittee chair Lord Wood of Anfield told the BBC it was a "struggle to find where in government" there was a focus on ageing and the "transformational effects" it was going to have on people.
The report also found that the crisis in adult social care "remains a scandal" which needs to be addressed urgently.
Young people will be hit hardest by successive governments' failure to focus on financial and societal challenges caused by an ageing population, a House of Lords report has suggested.
It also said an ageing population will need more care workers, leaving fewer workers for other parts of the economy.
"To successfully confront this challenge, the approach to financial management of today's and tomorrow's young people will need to change."

title: Banks win bid to block $3.6 billion mass forex UK lawsuit
summary:
LONDON, Dec 18 (Reuters) - Major banks including JPMorgan, UBS and Citigroup on Thursday won their bid to block a 2.7 billion-pound ($3.6 billion) mass ​lawsuit over alleged foreign exchange rigging.
The lawsuit, which was also brought against Barclays, MUFG and NatWest, was based on findings made by the European Commission, which fined banks more than 1 billion euros ($1.1 billion) in 2019.
The CAT said ​the case could be brought on an opt-in basis, though it accepted that ‌would effectively end the litigation.
Evans' case was revived by the Court of Appeal in 2023, but the banks' appeal was upheld by the United Kingdom's Supreme Court on Thursday.
Judge Vivien Rose said the Competition Appeal Tribunal "was right to assess the merits of the claim as weak".
